cwe_description: The product does not properly control the allocation and maintenance of a limited resource, thereby enabling an attacker to exhaust the resource.
explanation: The code calculates dense_shape->NumElements(), which represents the total number of elements in the dense tensor. This value can be extremely large if the input dense_shape tensor contains large dimensions. The subsequent line gtl::InlinedVector<int64, 8> std_order(dense_shape->NumElements(), 0); attempts to allocate a vector of int64 elements with a size equal to dense_shape->NumElements(). If an attacker provides a dense_shape with sufficiently large dimensions, dense_shape->NumElements() will be a very large positive number. This will cause an attempt to allocate an extremely large amount of memory (e.g., multiple exabytes), leading to an Out-of-Memory (OOM) error and a Denial of Service (DoS) for the application. This is an instance of uncontrolled resource consumption.

cwe_description: The software reads data past the end, or before the beginning, of the intended buffer.
explanation: The code checks if the input 'indices' is a matrix but does not validate that its second dimension (number of columns) is greater than zero. If 'indices' is a matrix with zero columns (e.g., shape [N, 0]), the loop iterates based on the first dimension, and the access 'indices->matrix<int64>()(i, 0)' will attempt to read from an invalid memory location, leading to an out-of-bounds read.
